name: Distributed Holographic Storage
description: The ability of a swarm to store information (patterns) in the relative positions and interactions of its agents, such that the removal of a subset of agents degrades the resolution but does not destroy the information.
findings: A swarm trained to form a ring structure maintained the shape (Error 0.22) even after 50% of the agents were removed.
The memory was sustained by a 'Virtual Pheromone' field generated collectively by the agents.
This confirms that NRM systems exhibit 'Holographic' properties: the whole is encoded in the parts.
implications: Swarm memory is highly robust to damage.
Information is not stored in any single agent but in the *relationships* between them.
This enables 'Graceful Degradation' rather than catastrophic failure.
